participants.participant: Philippe Bordenave, Senior Executive Vice-President, Head of Group Finance and Development

plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the presentation of BNP Paribas 2008 Third Quarter Results. For your information, this conference is being recorded. Slides of the presentation are available on BNP Paribas Investor Relations website www.invest.bnpparibas.com. .
I would now like to hand the call over to Philippe Bordenave, Senior Executive Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer.

Hello, everybody. Thank you for attending this telephone conference. Well, we are facing the, say, the results of a period which has been impacted by an unprecedented crisis. Clearly, the impact of the financial crisis this quarter is indeed much higher than in previous quarters for BNP Paribas, but what has happened this quarter is of a completely different nature than in the previous quarters.

In fact, if you look at the kind of normal crisis regime, I would say BNP Paribas continues to be less affected by markdowns on toxic exposures than most peers. The impact of markdown this quarter is around 400 million out of the 1.6 billion total impact, and those 400 million are very, is a very moderate figure compared to peers. And please remember that we have not been avoiding markdowns by reclassifying assets from the trading books to the banking book, unlike other banks.

On the same mode, I would say that the monoline have been provided for at the level of 460 million, so it's again, the cost of monoline this quarter, it comes in the cost of risk, because the monolines inflations are doubtful. So, this is also something, which we are used to see, well, it is a pity, I hope it's not going to last too long. But it's something, which is kind of usual level and again it compares favorably with our competitors. But in addition to these now "usual" markdowns, what has happened this quarter is that the crisis of liquidity and of confidence and of all markets has peaked into what we could call a kind of a systemic risk events, putting the weakest financial institutions into survival mode. Some of these weakened situations have been rescued by the way, including the GSCs but with negative impact on the per shares as you've seen. And others have left, has been left into default, such as Lehman Brothers and such as also on a smaller scale, the Icelandic banks. And especially the Lehman failure has been the biggest default in the financial system in the recent years and clearly the defaults have had the direct impact on all banks and financial institutions working with them, including us.

And this additional cost of the crisis, linked to the one-time default of financial institutions, adds up to around 800 million, so half of the total impact of the financial crisis for us. We believe that following the vigorous interventions of government in Europe and in the States, this systemic risk is now addressed and so we should not suffer these types of losses in the future. We need – of course, we need to remain vigilant and to handle each situation with extreme care, but it shouldn't, I mean, be replicated in the future to such a level.

And you should remember that even with this increased toll paid to the financial crisis and to the systemic risks having materialized, BNP Paribas is generating a net profit of close to 1 billion – 900 million this quarter and this confirms the relative resilience of our diversified and prudent business model, I think. So this is a way to look at our overperformance, I would say, the impact of an unprecedented crisis on our results. I think that we can have a kind of summary of this by looking at slides on the slide of the return on equity, which is – slide 13, where you see normally, it's going to come on your screen, where you can see that even in such an environment, the retail banking of BNP Paribas generated 1 billion for the quarter and for the whole of the year, well, for nine months of 2008, pre-tax return equity of 29%. Asset management and services were 134 million and 32% over the nine full months – first months.

And even CIB, which is breaking even – just breaking even this quarter generated 12% as the return equity, pre-tax over the nine first months, which is I would say quite decent for such a year. And at the level of the group, we generated the first tax return on equity of a little bit more than 13%, with 4.4 billion net income after tax, which is I think, well, the evidence that BNP Paribas is able to generate revenues and earnings even in the more stressed situations.

Now another way to look at it – at our overperformance, I think is to look at the underlying trend. And clearly, if you look beyond the impact of the crisis at the underlying trend of the businesses, it's clear that our organic growth is well, it keeps growing and is even kind of reinforced by the crisis, ironically, due to the increase in attractivity of our bank, in comparison with this number of their competitors. And I would like to lead you through a few slides, only if you want – don't worry. First, about CIB on slide 24, to show that the clients' revenues in the market activities and the financing activities as well of course, are high and keeps being high quarter after quarter during this crisis, and so are relatively stable, which is a kind of a reassuring message beyond the ups and downs of the trading results.

And clearly, and it's said on slide 25, we have seen a high commercial business volume in – across the board in CIB, especially this quarter in the, I mean the third quarter at the moment of the collapse of Lehman, there has been the kind of even additional volume due to the replacement of clients transactions formally with Lehman. But they came – I think they came to us rather than coming to somebody else, maybe, well more because of our enhanced attractiveness. We are also seeing the good conditions and improving conditions in the financing businesses, with wider margins, shorter maturities and stricter covenants and so on, which shows that, I would say, beyond the market crisis, the underlying trend in CIB is positive.

In Asset Management & Services on page 23, I would like to stress the very strong performance in terms of inflows. I think we are among the very small number of big banks having a positive net asset inflows into third quarter of €7.4 billion, which is quite striking, and it comes from all the businesses in Asset Management & Services, and especially, I would like to stress the very good performance of the private banking with 3.3 billion positive net inflows, while so many banks are seeing outflows. And the very good performance of the Asset Management business as well with 3.5 billion positive net inflows and primarily in money market funds, which shows that we are seen, to some extent, as a safe haven, and we are benefiting from the flight of quality. And so the assets and the management at 542 billion are almost stable, in the third quarter, which is really a very good performance.

And now if I come to the retail activity, starting with French retail on page 16, I would like to stress that we opened 50,000 new accounts in net figures, net from the closing, the closed accounts and it's an amount which is quite high. I remind you that given the demographics in France and our market share, and we need something like 80,000 new accounts per year to keep our market share, so at the nine months we are almost twice that level, meaning that really, we are increasing our market share in retail in France. And I will like also to stress the very good development of the business, with corporate clients, with both a sharp growth in outstanding loans and very good cross-selling results, and also, very good trends in side deposits.

And so, we have a growth in outstandings in France of both loans and deposits of around 10%, which is quite good. And well, which shows that the business is doing well. In Italy, as well, on page 18, we have a strong growth in outstanding loans and deposits, around 10%, again depending on the products for loans and mortgages, plus 7.6%; consumer lending, 11.7%; corporate, even more, 18%; and deposits, 4% in the context where to the Italian households have a kind of a trend towards bonds at the moment. But – so 4% is a good achievement in the Italian context and definitely the loan growth is also beating the market. So we are gaining market share clearly in Italy. To a certain extent as far as corporate clients are concerned, we are regaining market share after say, some of years where BNL had seen its position eroded among Italy and corporate. So since BNL is part of BNP Paribas Group, the trend has been reversed and we are gaining market share.

The same is also valid for BancWest on the next page, page 19 and we're beyond the revenues figures, which are say, handicapped by the one-off loss on Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, because it's, it comes on revenues here because it's about shares. And beyond the negative dollar effect, I mean the revenues, at a constant exchange rate and excluding the one-off loss, are growing by 13.4%, which is extremely strong in the U.S. environment and clearly is indicating a market share gain. And you can see that the deposits are growing by 7.7%, the loans by 13%. So clearly, the volumes are very healthy and growing faster than the average of the market.

And as far as the emerging markets are concerned on the next page, page 20, yes, we are developing in a certain number of countries throughout the Mediterranean region and Turkey and Ukraine at a very fast pace and we are very pleased both to increase the number of customers, we have now 4.5 million customers and to increase the volumes of deposits plus 28% over one year. In those countries, we care, it's very important to grow the deposits and the loans in parallel in order to avoid any liquidity, any local liquidity issue. And so this is what we are doing.

So overall, all those figures, I think, are showing that we are enjoying a strong organic growth, which is, well, somewhat different from what some of our competitors are experiencing at the moment. And on top of this organic growth, I would like briefly, we could set the peak of the day, but I would just like to remind you with a cushion of 40, which is bringing a real expansion of our European footprint, which is really creating for BNP Paribas a unique positioning in Europe, with Eurozone is number one from a deposit base. And which is really the kind of transforming deal increasing very significantly the size and the scope, the size of BNP Paribas and of the capital of BNP Paribas, which is going to bring something like 16 billion Tier 1 capital and the scope of BNP Paribas. And so by looking at those underlying trends, I would say, it becomes clear that BNP Paribas is going to come out of the crisis, when the price is going to come down, there will be, I would say, two types of players.

We are going to be among the players, with a stronger position, a wider scope. So we'll be wider scope, stronger position and a reinforced capital base without any dilution because this increase in capital will have been done in parallel with enlargement of this group. And it's going to be very different from the number of competitors who are going to come out of the crisis with a kind of smaller scope, or, they will have shrunk their activities because of the crisis on the defensive mode.

And they will have to utilize their shareholders by issuing a different type of Tier 1 products, expensive Tier 1 products. And so, they will have probably, at the most, less revenues and more capital to compensate at the same time, so it's – which is the definition of the dilution. And so, I think that this is what I wanted to say as kind of a introductory remark.
And I'm now ready to answer to your questions.
Thank you, sir. . We will take our first question today from Kian Abouhossein from JP Morgan. Please go ahead.

Yes, hi. I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more color on the CIB negative revenue comment for October. I assume it's in the equity derivative business post dislocation. And if you could give us a little bit more color, if this is related to single option or index option flow business and also in the structuring business, kind of an indication of in what area?

The second question is related to slide, page 75 on your commercial real estate exposure. I was wondering if you could give me an idea, what the other division actually is in terms of growth exposure and why that exposure has increased relative to the second quarter. And the third question I have is on the consumer finance provisions, which are running roughly at 200 basis points. If you could give any – if you could discuss, maybe how this should progress going forward in your view. Thank you.

Yes, Kian. So, let's answer to your question one after the other. On CIB, yes we have slightly negative revenues in October. Well, I think CIB revenues are roughly made of three parts, as we are showing them regularly. The kind of stable part is coming from the financing businesses and they are relatively stable around the 200 plus millions in and it's financing activities, revenues are relatively stable. So this is – this is not changed in October. And then so the – I would say the negative revenues, the losses came from the market, and in fact October markets were characterized by a situation, which was not only as hectic as in September, but even more, I would say and it has been, well, a period of extreme turbulence.

And I would like to say that especially well, on the fixed-income side, I would say it's not brilliant, it has been difficult like I would say, since the beginning of the year, maybe a little bit more in these extremely stress periods. But it's close to zero, but slightly positive. And so the losses we incurred, and which are bringing back to zero minus, I would say the total revenues of the business line are coming from equity derivatives, in the context of equity markets, which are – I mean which were extremely, I mean, in an well, hectic and an unprecedented way. And I would like to, as I was sure you would ask the question, Kian. I have prepared a slide for you and will – it's a slide of the VIX index, the index of the volatility in the equity markets.

And so, I think it's going to be put on your screens now, and if – well this VIX index has already captured to the attention of analysts and investors in July 2007, because at the beginning of the crisis we had seen a peak at the level of 30. And at that time, people – old people like myself had reminded everybody that in the past we had seen worst levels than 30, in fact in 98 or 2002 this index had been up to 40. And since in the slide, which is posted on your screens, normally it's very clear that since July 2007, there are several peaks and it's a very hectic evolution of this index between 20 and 30, several peaks at 30, and in September it went up to 40 and came back to very high levels, already seen in crisis times like '98 or 2002. But October, I mean it, was another story, I mean, it doubled from 40 to 80.

And with several ups and downs between 70 and 50 in a few days or in one day in certain case. So it has been a real unprecedented period in terms of managing derivatives, equity derivatives books because the delta hedging becomes almost impossible because the management of the Greeks is something which is extremely, extremely difficult or even impossible in certain cases. And so we were in a situation where clearly the equity derivatives teams were facing a situation where – well that was extremely difficult for them to cope with that. So the result is that they had losses and well clearly the revenues of equity are negative in October and so this is the story I would say.

In equity derivatives, to answer even more precisely to your question because your question is very precise, it's a little bit across the board. It's not especially a certain category of team, it's definitely not the Volkswagen situation people saw at the same time, which was part of the hurricane I would say. But it's not that, it happens that we were not involved especially in that stock. But it's more across – well a lot of difficult situations handled – difficulty are handled across the board in equity.
Now coming to your second question about the page 75, we – well, you are referring to the...
The 4.8 in the Other. First of all I was wondering what that is? And secondly, why it's increasing so materially from the second quarter?
Well, it's – yeah it's a 4.8 billion. Okay? It is that in U.S.
Yes, that's right.

Which is coming from 2.9 billion in June, this is your question? Well it's not an increase in actual position in fact. It's an enlargement of the definition since June. It's non-owner occupied commercial or industrial loans with collateral. And it's not a direct real estate risk in fact. Even if it's classified in – it's classified in residential – in commercial real estate because we're taking the good as collateral, the property as collateral. But it's more – it was re-cost on the client on the corporate sales. So it's pretty much more commercial loan, and the increase is just due to a reclassification, a change of definition, enlargement of the definition.

Now your next question is about consumer finance and the 200 basis points. And even, I would say, the 230 basis points in the third quarter, 200 is the average for the first nine months, for the third quarter, we have seen 230 basis points. Well, consumer finance is traditionally an early indicator of the cost of risk when an economy is slowing down. I think that's what's happening is that, and just that. We are clearly seeing the beginning of a recession in Europe. We have seen a negative evolution of the gross, the product in several countries in the third quarter – in the second quarter, sorry, compared to the first quarter and we're already seeing the first signs of again a negative evolution in the third quarter.

And so this recession, beginning of a recession in Europe is taking its toll on the consumer finance activities. This is very clear and I think it's an evolution of all banks – for all banks involved in consumer finance business. We – what is the characteristics as far as we are concerned is that, we are among the countries most affected by this evolution I think, which are U.K., Ireland and Spain. And we are only active in significant way in Spain. We are not active in the U.K. or in Ireland. But in Spain, we do have some activity and on top of that, we 're seeing also the beginning of a significant deterioration of the credit quality also in Eastern Europe, in the first belt, I would say, of Eastern Europe countries, Poland, Czech Republic, Hungary and so on where our exposure is smaller.

And so that I would say that most of the explanation of this increase in the cost of risk in consumer finance is coming from Spain and Eastern Europe. And well, we are taking action, of course. We are taking a number of actions in order to curb this evolution, this trend. But that kind of action requires some time before being translated into the figures. We are, well given the fact that the economy in Europe is probably going to remain relatively sluggish for the next few quarters in 2009, we are not expecting a strong improvement of these figures to become .

We – clearly we were enjoying a low level of cost of risk in this business, with something like 100 basis points one year ago or something like that, one and half years ago. We are – well, we're now at 200 something – 200, 250, I think it's a level which is – well, which remains – well, which is high – which is higher, but remains such as allowing significant profitability of the businesses in question, because the margins are adjusted and are relatively wide in that business. And we are of course adapting to the situation by, I would say, slowing down the production of new loans in the countries, where we are – where we see the most of the problem, especially in Spain, where we have capped the production by 40% this quarter. And we – the same in Eastern Europe and at the same time, we keep growing and well developing the business in the rest of Europe, where we see, I would say, a limited deterioration, only a limited deterioration of the credit quality. So I think that well we – it's really due – well, in our case it's really due to the Spanish situation mostly, in terms of volumes and we are taking action to limit that as much as possible.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
Our next question today will come from John Beisler with Nomura. Please go ahead.

Yeah, hi everybody. I had two questions, please. The first one was on slide 41, where you outlined your cost of risk by division. We heard from SocGen earlier that they kind of went through again what they estimated their mid-cycle cost of risk was and gave an idea of a stress test, where in a recession the cost of risk might be typically double the normalized rate. So I just wondered if you could remind us again what you feel your normalized rate is by division and on the assumption we are going into a recession, whether a double that rate might be appropriate at a stress test.

And I had a second question, which was just on your hybrids. You show us on slide 31 that hybrids pro forma for Fortis are now up to about 20% of Tier 1 capital. And I just wondered if there was a hard upper limit, beyond which you'd have to start to think about measures to increase common equity if there was further losses because of the market environment ahead? Thanks.

Yes. Well the cost of risk, well the definition of a normalized cost of risk is a perilous exercise. We, yes, it's precisely well kind of giving a flavor of it that we are giving the slide 41 with – we are providing you with an overview long-term, overview of what happened in the past. So, you – well I don't want to give you really specific figures because it's something which is difficult. I may make – on the basis of slide 41, I can make some qualitative comments. In the French Retail Banking and taking the five points – the five activities because it's where the cost of risk is lying, on the French Retail business, we have a very low custom risk, we are half – well it's more or less half the cost of risk of most of our competitors in France, including the one you have quoted.

And we really think that we have made a very strong selection of the quality of our clients on the time and that we in a period of recession or in period of financial recession, the gap between our cost of risk and the cost of risk of competitors should not only remain the same, but even widened because it's when you stretched (40.42) the environment that the difference in cost of risks are showing up the most. So we can only expect an increase in cost of risk in a risk while in a risk scenario environment, which is looming for the whole of Europe. But we are rather confident that it shouldn't be that big and certainly not doubling the current level or the level of 2006 or 2007, while which I think that really the quality of the portfolio is very good.

In Italy, it's the same, we should see an increase in the cost of risk due to the economic environment. Well, to a certain extent, we have provided – we have reserved in Italy, I would say, following the Group's (41.55), so we are well reserved, like we were in the Group. And so already the best views are the 90 days – those views are qualified as doubtful and are reserved, which is not the case of the Italian banks, as you know. And so we are ahead, if you want, of the trend. To some extent, we have the kind of excellent – beginning of the kind of excellent provisioning with the best use provisioning. So we probably would see a deterioration. So again we are not expecting a quite doubling from the current level, far, far from that.

Now in BancWest – in BancWest, the cost of risk at the moment is the addition of two paths, the red path on the slide, slide 41 you are referring to is the kind of exceptional path, which is the direct impact of the financial crisis and should come down to the euro progressively. We hope that the red – the green path, sorry, which is more normal cost of risk on the loan portfolio is increasing very fast in the U.S. environment and it may keep increasing further, depending on the depths of the recession in BancWest. But as the grey path, the additional exceptional cost of risk on especially on the portfolio, on the investment portfolio, the impairments of new investment portfolio should come down with time. And that the total of both, may be not going to grow that much.

And then PF, Personal Finance, while we have just talked about it, probably it will keep growing. I mean we were in the region of 130, as I would think. Now we are more in the region of 230, while it may go further than that. And in CIB, in CIB I think the quarter is characterized by the Lehman failure, so there is a big one-off effect I would say on CIB. But, the – if you adjust for that, you see that arrange (44.51) of the cost of the risk, which is the underlying cost of risk, remains very low at the moment, very, very low, last one almost zero in terms of basis points. And in this quarter it swung from a net price back to a positive, though this quarter it's 24 basis points. So it's – and I think that this kind of level maybe 20 basis points is a more normal level for CIB and in the crisis while it could go up to, you see that in 2002, 2003, it went up to 60, so it gives you a flavor of what it can be in threat conditions.

So that's it I think, so I don't know if I have completely answered your question. But at least you have some ideas of our way of thinking about the cost of risks. So overall, the trend is up clearly given the environment. But given the levels we have reached now, maybe not in a dramatic way.

Now you are referring on slide 31 for hybrid, let me go to slide 31. Yes, yes, the Fortis acquisition will bring both, I would say hybrids and common equity, it will bring 9 billion capital increase, which is going to be a real common equity, plus 6 billions in minority interest. And so it's going to bring a real common equity for a significant amount, I would say, plus something like 3 billion hybrids. So, yes, there is a balance and the French State is only bringing hybrids, but this is fortunate I would say.

So, yes, there is a balance to be kept. You know that in the – in Europe, the accepted – the regulatorily acceptable level of hybrid is different from one country to another. We were living in France, with the feeling of 25% of hybrids. And we – well we managed the bank by growing in parallel the common – the common equity and the hybrids, in order to keep this proportion more or less 75%, 25%. And there are currently discussions at the European level in order to harmonize these proportions and so that the middle point, which could be chosen or has been already chosen, it has been returned already, I think it's official, the kind of compromise, which has been found between different countries is to increase the proportion of hybrids, to accept the proportion of hybrid up to 35%, having in mind that in certain countries, it was much more than that, even 50 or something like that.

So we may have the opportunity of increasing a little bit of the proportion of hybrids in context. Well anyway, I think it's healthy exercise to keep I would say hybrids as a proportion of total of Q1, which is not too high. I think 25% when service, something which is reasonable. And we – well, and we are generating, the good thing is that with the results quarter-to-quarter we are generating common equity and not hybrid. So it's helping us in the evolution.
Yeah, it was certainly helpful. Thank you.
You're welcome.
Our next question today will come from Antonio Guglielmi with Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.
Hello? Can you hear me?
Yes, Antonio, go ahead.

Yes. Good afternoon. Just a quick question and it's on leverage. Your balance sheet size is even bigger now after the Fortis acquisition, with 2.5 trillion. And let's say that the equity to asset ratio is effectively below the average in Europe. Would you agree in identifying these as the major question mark of your story at the moment? And if yes, what do you see as potential actions improving the ratio, I'm thinking about available for sale reserve for instance. And also, if you can provide us an update on the dividend expectations for this year. Thank you.

Antonio, the leverage ratio is a kind of outdated way of -- a very simplistic and outdated way of analyzing a bank's balance sheet, I think. It's what I call Basel 0. And I'm not the only one to do so, by the way. I have observed that Deutsche Bank has explained that depending on the accounting standards you have a very different leverage ratio. And they have even provided the market with a slide explaining that because they are reporting their results in both and IFRS because in the IFRS it's 2 trillion at the end of September. And in U.S. GAAP, it's 1.3. So, I mean, it's one third of the balance sheet is about so you can improve easily your leverage ratio, if you change your accounting standards from the IFRS to U.S. GAAP, first.

Another sure way to improve the leverage ratio is to build a structured investment vehicle, you know, a SIV, so because it goes out of your balance sheet and with off balance sheet commitments you have exactly the same risk in practice as has been shown by the crisis. But the leverage ratio is quite okay. So really the leverage ratio, I think, it's not something, which is really significant. I think that really it's difficult to stop talking I think. It's difficult to analyze a bank's balance sheet because it's very complicated are there are a lot of products. And even more, the off balance sheet commitments, which can be even more dangerous than the balance sheet volume. And so really I think the story of the regulation over the last – and the rating agencies as well – over the last years, has been to try to improve the merger of the risk and to – trying to come to a merger which is as much risk sensitive as possible.

And so the move from Basel I to Basel II is clearly inspired by this idea of coming closer to the risk. And really I think that at this stage I don't see any better merger of the real leverage of the Bank than the Basel II ratio. And I think that we should stick to that. And as it's not completely comparative due to a certain number of risks, we shall not taken into account – still not taken into account in the Basel II ratio, they have invented the so-called Pillar II in order to add to the level which is required from the banks, the standard level, 4%, 8% to add to that layer, which tries to take into consideration the other risk, which of course the regulators know, or are supposed to know. And know, in fact, if really I think, if they are doing their job properly.

And so this level of the Tier II level, minimum level, is also I think showing what is the real leverage of a bank meaning that, if beyond the Pillar I measure if a bank is leveraged in another way, which is less easy or not quantified, not captured by the Pillar I, the regulator can impose a higher Tier I on that bank in order to make sure that, I would say, the risks are properly covered by the Tier I capital. So I think it's the way it works and any shortcut I think is really counter-productive in the analysis of the risk.
And so this is about – now the dividend, the dividend, well as we always say, we are not changing, as we always say the dividend is -.
available for us.
Sorry. The dividend is – hello, Antonio, are you there?
Yes, yes thanks.

Sorry. So the dividend is the decision of the Board, which is taken, you know, it's going to be taken in February upon the full-year results. We don't want to anticipate or to pre-empt this decision. And when we are calculating our ratios, we are taking just as a kind of theoretical assumption, the same payout ratio than last year, which is 40%. But for sure over nine months, our net income, Group share, is 4.4 billion, so we are clearly among the banks at least able to pay a dividend, which there are not that many today. And it's something to bear in mind, but I think that's all we can say at this stage.
Thank you very much.
Welcome.
We'll take our next question today from Jean-Pierre Lambert with KBW. Please go ahead.
Yes, good afternoon.
Good afternoon.

A few questions. The first one is regarding the performance of revenues in the corporate investment bank (sic) [Corporate and Investment Banking] , I'm talking up to the second – the third quarter. Is there a form of, I mean aren't we exposed to a form of inflation of revenues? Because on the first hand, you have a switch into more stable, more attractive banks in this environment, which you benefit from, but on the other hand also maybe there is an additional activity related to volatility in the markets. So these two phenomena maybe will disappear over time, not disappear fully, but maybe we're seeing a kind of peak. And we might have the impression that revenues are very strong, but maybe there will be a correction as the competitive aspect maybe slows down and the volatility changes as well?

That was the first point. The second was regarding Fortis. I mean, do you see some legal risk in the transactions in view of the series of legal challenges we see both into The Netherlands and Belgium? And also in your information, is the franchise suffering by trans leaving the bank on the country benefiting for the moment. Thank you very much.

Yes. On the CIB revenues, I think we will have to make a distinction between the financing revenues and the market revenues, I think. The two situations are very different. On the financing revenues part, I think clearly that we are benefiting from, yes, from new clients and good evolution of the business. But also from widened margins, better conditions and I think this is going – this is poised to stay like that for some time now. I think really that what we are going to – the crisis is really a crisis of disintermediation. Over the last few years, the financing businesses were really in competition with kind of shortcut or short circuits which were organized by investment banks and investors. And all that has disappeared now.

There is a reluctance of all the non-banking world to take credit risk. And so I think that to a certain extent we are back to a period where banks were more or less the only ones to lend money to corporates, to the economy. And this is favorable in terms of margins. It is favorable in terms of volumes. So and this is going to remain like that for quite some time, I think. It's slightly early that... So this, I wouldn't say that on that part there is the risk that it would vanish rapidly.

On the market revenues, there you have something different, because you have the client business and then the trading revenues. And clearly, even if both are linked, in our case, as we don't have significant prop trading activities, I would say, both are the two sides of the same coin.

But you may have a lot of client revenues and not a lot of gains, because if – and it's what happened in October for example, where you may have a lot of client business, due to as you said some extreme volatility or – clients in October, clearly in equity derivative clients, were one-way. So up to now, we can say – up to now the difference in procyclicality between Basel II and Basel I, up to now has been relatively limited. But it may worsen in the future, but well, we are observing that with care, we are watching that with a lot of care and up to now the difference is not too – . I remind you that in theory at least, the procyclicality of Basel II should be mitigated by a certain number of factors. The first factor is that in the internal models, the rating, the internal rating is theoretically attributed through the cycle, with a through cycle view and as such, it shouldn't change too much in bad times or in good times. And so this rating is fixing the probability of default, which is taken in the models.

And the other big parameter of the model, which is the loss given before, is also supposed to be relatively immune from the cycle because it has to be a downturn loss given before, so it has to be a worst-case scenario if you want. So it shouldn't be changed either, normally if, even in bad time. So we, in theory, but I agree with you that practice sometimes differs from theory. In theory, it shouldn't be too much procyclical, I definitely expect, like you, that it will be somewhat procyclical compared with Basel I. We have seen that at the level of 10 basis points in the beginning of the year and we are watching the situation.

And now the next question about the monolines, yes, the monolines, they have, yes, of course they are losing money in Q3, I mean for the same reasons then our exposure on them is growing, because they are marking their commitments to us, they are – what they owe – what they potentially owe to the market is increasing because of the widening of the spreads. So the widening of the – of the general widening of the spreads is, among different consequences, as a consequence that the theoretical debt, potential debt of the monoline, is increasing and as such they have to mark it in their exempt P&L, I guess, I'm not an expert in insurance, especially monoline insurance accounting. But they have to mark the increase in the potential debt, they have vis-à-vis the market. But it doesn't mean that these variations in spreads are translating into immediate losses because, actual losses if you want, because, beyond the accounting losses, because the monoline system, as the general monoline practice, the documentation of protection as well on CDOs or CLOs or whatever, is much more protective for the liquidity than the ISDA standard usual CDS standard, CDS contract.

The events triggering the payments by the monoline is not the variation of the mark-to-market but it's restricted to only interest shortfalls and failure to pay, default principal at the end, at the maturity of the bond, or upon the winding up of the CDO. So the – as a result, if you want, monoline has the possibility to pay only – to pay the interest shortfalls only during the whole life of the contract and to pay the principal write-down only at the end, at the final legal maturity of the bond, which could be in 10 or 15 or 20 years time. So the liquidity of the monoline is protected and this is why they I am not bankrupt as of now and this is why they keep a good rating as well. I mean, even if they are not, all of them are not, not necessarily AAA anymore, but now AA, I think that's which are showing that everything is not that bad, because they have a lot of – they don't have to post collateral, because they don't have any liquidity issue, and they have to – they have the timing for them as well. So this is why, and in between the mark-to-market may change and each time the spreads are becoming – are tightening, in fact it's a reverse effect, so the situation of the monoline is not necessarily desperate, at least not all of them.
